briefdescription.para: Connect to the FTP server to default port (21) of the specified host.
Connect to the FTP server to any port of the specified host.

detaileddescription.para: By default (port = 0), connection is made to default FTP port (21) of the specified host.

sectiondef.header: Functions for managing the FTP connection

briefdescription.para: Aborts the download currently in process, returns true if ok, false if an error occurred.
Gracefully closes the connection with the server.
Send the specified command to the FTP server.

detaileddescription.para: ret specifies the expected result.

simplesect.para: true if the command has been sent successfully, else false.

briefdescription.para: Returns the last command result, i.e.

detaileddescription.para: the full server reply for the last command.

briefdescription.para: Send the specified command to the FTP server and return the first character of the return code.
Sets the transfer mode to ASCII.

detaileddescription.para: It will be used for the next transfer.

briefdescription.para: Sets the transfer mode to binary.

detaileddescription.para: It will be used for the next transfer.

briefdescription.para: If pasv is true, passive connection to the FTP server is used.

detaileddescription.para: This is the default as it works with practically all firewalls. If the server doesn't support passive mode, you may call this function with false as argument to use an active connection.

briefdescription.para: Sets the password to be sent to the FTP server to be allowed to log in.
Sets the transfer mode to the specified one.

detaileddescription.para: It will be used for the next transfer.
If this function is never called, binary transfer mode is used by default.

briefdescription.para: Sets the user name to be sent to the FTP server to be allowed to log in.
Change the current FTP working directory.

detaileddescription.para: Returns true if successful.

briefdescription.para: Create the specified directory in the current FTP working directory.

detaileddescription.para: Returns true if successful.

briefdescription.para: Returns the current FTP working directory.
Rename the specified src element to dst.

detaileddescription.para: Returns true if successful.

briefdescription.para: Remove the specified directory from the current FTP working directory.

detaileddescription.para: Returns true if successful.

briefdescription.para: Delete the file specified by path.

detaileddescription.para: Returns true if successful.

briefdescription.para: Returns true if the given remote file exists, false otherwise.
The GetList() function is quite low-level.

detaileddescription.para: It returns the list of the files in the current directory. The list can be filtered using the wildcard string.
If wildcard is empty (default), it will return all files in directory. The form of the list can change from one peer system to another. For example, for a UNIX peer system, it will look like this:

para.verbatim: -r--r--r-- 1 guilhem lavaux 12738 Jan 16 20:17 cmndata.cpp -r--r--r-- 1 guilhem lavaux 10866 Jan 24 16:41 config.cpp -rw-rw-rw- 1 guilhem lavaux 29967 Dec 21 19:17 cwlex_yy.c -rw-rw-rw- 1 guilhem lavaux 14342 Jan 22 19:51 cwy_tab.c -r--r--r-- 1 guilhem lavaux 13890 Jan 29 19:18 date.cpp -r--r--r-- 1 guilhem lavaux 3989 Feb 8 19:18 datstrm.cpp

detaileddescription.para: But on Windows system, it will look like this:

simplesect.para: true if the file list was successfully retrieved, false otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Returns the file size in bytes or -1 if the file doesn't exist or the size couldn't be determined.

detaileddescription.para: Notice that this size can be approximative size only and shouldn't be used for allocating the buffer in which the remote file is copied, for example.

briefdescription.para: This function returns the computer-parsable list of the files in the current directory (optionally only of the files matching the wildcard, all files by default).

detaileddescription.para: This list always has the same format and contains one full (including the directory path) file name per line.

simplesect.para: true if the file list was successfully retrieved, false otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Creates a new input stream on the specified path.

detaileddescription.para: You can use all but the seek functionality of wxStreamBase. wxStreamBase::Seek() isn't available on all streams. For example, HTTP or FTP streams do not deal with it. Other functions like wxStreamBase::Tell() are not available for this sort of stream, at present.
You will be notified when the EOF is reached by an error.

simplesect.para: Returns NULL if an error occurred (it could be a network failure or the fact that the file doesn't exist).

briefdescription.para: Initializes an output stream to the specified file.

detaileddescription.para: The returned stream has all but the seek functionality of wxStreams. When the user finishes writing data, he has to delete the stream to close it.

simplesect.para: An initialized write-only stream. Returns NULL if an error occurred (it could be a network failure or the fact that the file doesn't exist).

briefdescription.para: not set by user explicitly.
Transfer modes used by wxFTP.
Default constructor.
Destructor will close the connection if connected.
wxFTP can be used to establish a connection to an FTP server and perform all the usual operations.

detaileddescription.para: Please consult the RFC 959 (http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc959/) for more details about the FTP protocol.
wxFTP can thus be used to create a (basic) FTP client.

To use a command which doesn't involve file transfer (i.e. directory oriented commands) you just need to call a corresponding member function or use the generic wxFTP::SendCommand() method. However to actually transfer files you just get or give a stream to or from this class and the actual data are read or written using the usual stream methods.
Example of using wxFTP for file downloading:
To upload a file you would do (assuming the connection to the server was opened successfully):
Library:wxNet
Category:Networking
